case_title: Sh. AZIZ-UR-RAHMAN AND Another vs BAHAWALNAGAR CO OPERATIVE COMMISSION SHOP LTD. AND Other

accussed_details.name: Sheikh Rahmat Ullah
allegation: Obstruction in removal of pledged goods

accussed_details.name: Muhammad Ali
allegation: Denial of liability for pledged goods

complaint_summary: The plaintiff filed a suit for recovery of Rs. 25,405-13-6 against Bahawalpur Cotton Company for loans advanced on pledged seed cotton and cotton bales.
investigation_summary: The plaintiff verified the pledged goods through stockists and advanced loans based on assurances. Disputes arose over the sale of pledged goods and obstruction by one partner.
judgment_summary: The court partly accepted the appeal, disallowing interest awarded by the trial judge but upheld the liability of the defendants for the principal amount. The cross-objections filed by the plaintiff were dismissed.
punishment: Liability to repay Rs. 24,456-8-3 without interest.
legal_arguments: Plaintiff argued for recovery of loan based on pledged goods.
Defendants claimed negligence by plaintiff in selling goods timely.
Defendants denied liability for interest due to absence of contractual stipulation.
witnesses: Stockists (Sayyed Fateh Muhammad Shah, Malik Muhammad Ashiq)

witness_statement.Sheikh Abdur Rahman: Confirmed loans and pledges made to the plaintiff and described contractual terms.
witness_statement.Stockists: Verified possession of pledged goods and undertook to retain them until clearance by plaintiff.

key_issues: Obstruction in removal of pledged goods
Negligence in selling pledged goods timely

legal_terms.Pledge: A bailment of goods as security for payment of a debt or performance of a promise.
legal_terms.Bailment: Delivery of goods by one person to another for a specific purpose under a contract.

words_and_phrases.Collateral Security: Property pledged as security for a loan.
words_and_phrases.Constructive Delivery: Legal delivery of goods without physical transfer.

summary_vector_notes: The case involves a dispute over loans advanced by the plaintiff to the defendant firm against pledged goods. The court upheld the liability of the defendants for the principal amount but disallowed interest due to absence of contractual stipulation. The appeal was partly accepted, and cross-objections were dismissed.
